section.title: Initial setup
section.para: The Guacamole web application uses one main configuration file called guacamole.properties which must be in the classpath of your servlet container. This file is the common location for all configuration properties read by Guacamole or any extension of Guacamole, including authentication providers.
At the bare minimum, the guacamole.properties file provides four basic properties:

listitem.para: The host the Guacamole proxy daemon (guacd) is listening on. This is most likely localhost.
The port the Guacamole proxy daemon (guacd) is listening on. This is port 4822 by default.
The authentication provider to use when authenticating. Normally, this will be set to, BasicFileAuthenticationProvider which is the default authentication provider provided with Guacamole.

The directory to load extensions to Guacamole from. If you wish to use a custom authentication provider or custom hooks, the .jar file and all dependencies must be placed in the directory specified here.

section.title: Authentication
section.para: Guacamole's authentication model is simple and consists of a mapping of usernames to configurations. Each username has a corresponding password and associated set of configurations, and each configuration has a protocol and protocol-specific set of parameters. The example user-mapping.xml file included with Guacamole is a fairly good example of this concept.
Authentication is configured by editing guacamole.properties and setting the authentication provider property: auth-provider.
Guacamole comes with an authentication provider, BasicFileAuthProvider, which simply reads usernames and passwords from an XML file.

section.title: Adding users and connections
section.para: The default authentication provider used by Guacamole reads all username, password, and configuration information from a file called the "user mapping" (typically named user-mapping.xml). Other authentication providers can be written which read authentication information from other sources, but those are not documented here. To learn how to configure an authentication provider not included in the main Guacamole bundle, consult the documentation provided with that authentication provider.
